Graphical abstract Highlights ► β-CD-HMDI polymer coated Fe3O4 nanoparticles as efficient phase-transfer catalyst. ► Hetrogenous catalyst in nucleophilic substitution of benzyl halides. ► Conversion of benzyl halides to thiocyanate, azide, cyanide and acetate in water. ► This method is safe, cost effective and easy to operate. The polymer coated magnetic nanoparticles has gained significant attention for potential applications in biomedicine, separations, and magnetic storage. In this study, β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer coated Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticle as a novel class of hybrid organic/inorganic molecular catalyst was successfully prepared and evaluated as solid–liquid phase-transfer catalyst and molecular host system for nucleophilic substitution reactions. The nanocomposite has demonstrated the ability to catalytic the nucleophilic substitution reaction of benzyl halides with thiocyanate, azide, cyanide and acetate anions in water. No evidence for the formation of by-products for example isothiocyanate or alcohol was observed and the products obtained in pure form without further purification. The nanomagnetic polymer brush catalyst was easily removed from solution via application of a magnetic field, allowing straightforward recovery and reuse. Results obtained from scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and vibrating sample magnetometery (VSM) show that the synthesized magnetic nanocomposite are superparamagnetic with a mean diameter of 59nm. The grafting of β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer to Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticle is confirmed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). Keywords β-Cyclodextrin–polyurethane Magnetic nanoparticle Nucleophilic substitution Benzyl halide 1 Introduction Magnetic nanoparticles have been attracting increasing attention among the academic and industrial scientific community [1–3]. These nanoparticles, because of their high surface area and unique magnetic properties, have a broad range of potential uses in biomedical and catalyst support applications [4,5]. Iron oxides, magnetite (Fe3O4) and maghemite (γ-Fe2O3) are by far the most used magnetic nanoparticles, because they are much less toxic than their metallic counterparts, and they still have high saturation magnetization and superparamagnetic behavior, among which magnetite is a very promising choice due to its already proven biocompatibility [6]. In addition, previous investigations have shown that magnetite has relatively high LD50 values (400mg/kg in rats) and polymer-coated magnetite has not shown any acute or subacute toxicity in animal studies [7,8]. Magnetite nanoparticle can be easily formed at low temperatures under mild conditions and modified in terms of hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity to tune its dispersion stability in organic or aqueous media. Unfortunately, it often has lower surface areas compared to other, more traditional, microporous/mesoporous materials used as catalyst supports, limiting the total amount of active sites that can be grafted to the surface. Researchers have shown some success using nanoparticle supported dendrons and magnetic nanoparticle polymer brush materials to increase these loadings [9–11]. The functionalization and modification of iron oxide nanoparticles with various biocompatible and biodegradable materials in many different ways has been demonstrated [6,12,13]. A striking feature of the MNPs-supported catalysts is that they can be readily separated using an external magnet, which achieves simple separation of the catalysts without filtration. On the other hand, β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer form a whole new family of stationary microvessel and solid–liquid phase transfer catalyst, which form noncovalent inclusion complexes with a wide variety of lipophilic molecules by taking up a whole molecule, or some part of it into the lipophilic cavity of their β-cyclodextrin units [14–17]. In that regard and with a cost-cutting goal, we designed, novel magnetic nanoparticle supported polymeric phase transfer catalyst through the immobilization of β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer on magnetite, β-CDPU-MNPs, and the preliminary evaluation of its catalytic activity as solid–liquid phase-transfer catalyst and molecular host system for nucleophilic substitution reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 General Iron (II) chloride tetrahydrate (99%), iron (III) chloride hexahydrate (98%), benzyl halides and other chemical materials were purchased from Fluka and Merck and used without further purification. β-Cyclodextrin was heated at 80°C under vacuum for 30min before use to remove traces of moisture. Products were characterized by comparison of their physical data, IR and 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra with known samples. NMR spectra were recorded in CDCl3 on a Bruker Advance DPX 400MHz instrument spectrometer using TMS as internal standard. The purity determination of the products and reaction monitoring were accomplished by TLC on silica gel polygram SILG/UV 254 plates. The FT-IR spectra of CDPU-MNPs was measured as potassium bromide discs on a BOMEM MB-Series 1998 FT-IR Spectrophotometer. The particle morphology was examined by a SEM. The TGA curve of the β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer grafted onto Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles was recorded on a BAHR, SPA 503 at heating rates of 10°Cmin−1. The thermal behavior was studied by heating 1–3mg of samples in aluminum-crimped pans under nitrogen gas flow, over the temperature range of 25–500°C. 2.2 Preparation of β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer grafted onto Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles (β-CDPU-MNPs) Preparation β-CDPU-MNPs involved two steps. First, superparamagnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) were prepared via improved chemical coprecipitation method [18]. According to this method, FeCl2·4H2O (3.1736g, 1.6mmol) and FeCl3·6H2O (7.5684g, 2.8mmol) were dissolved in 320mL of deionized water, such that Fe2+/Fe3+ =1/1.75. The mixed solution was stirred under N2 at 80°C for 1h, 40mL of NH3·H2O was injected into the reaction mixture rapidly, stirred under N2 for another 1h and then cooled to room temperature. The precipitated particles were washed five times with hot water and separated by magnetic decantation. Finally, magnetic NPs were dried under vaccum at 70°C. For introducing of isocyanate groups onto the surface of the magnetic nanoparticles, in the second step, the MNPs powder (0.4g) was dispersed in DMF (30mL) by sonication and then hexamethylene diisocyanate (2.96g, 17.6mmol) in 5mL of dry DMF was added dropwise to the mixture. After mechanically agitation of mixture for 3h, to graft β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer onto the surface of MNPs, in the last step, two grams of β-CD (2g, 1.76mmol) was dissolved in 15mL of dry DMF and was added dropwise to reaction mixture. The mixture was stirred at 70°C for 3h. The precipitate was separated by magnetic decantation and washed with water and acetone several times. β-CDPU-MNPs was dried in vacuum for 24h. 2.3 Typical procedure for the nucleophilic substitution of benzyl halides catalyzed by β-CDPU-MNPs To a mixture of the benzyl halide (1.0mmol) and MY (Y:N3, SCN, OAc, CN) (2mmol) in water (5ml), β-CDPU-MNPs (0.1g) was added. The suspension was magnetically stirred under reflux conditions for the time shown in Table 1 . After complete consumption of starting material as judged by TLC (using n-hexane–ethylacetate as eluent), the catalyst was concentrated on the sidewall of the reaction vessel using an external magnet, the aqueous phase was separated by decantation and extracted with diethyl ether (2× 10mL). The extracted was dried with calcium chloride (CaCl2) and evaporated in vacuo to give corresponding product. The residual catalyst in the reaction vessel was washed and dried and then subjected to the next run directly. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Investigation around the approach of β-CDPU-MNPs preparation and its structural and morphological analysis Among all iron oxide NPs, magnetite (Fe3O4) exhibits the most interesting properties because the presence of non-equivalent iron cations in two valence states, Fe2+ and Fe3+, in the crystal structure gives rise to a unique magnetic structure [19]. Magnetite is easily prepared by adding a base to an aqueous mixture of Fe2+ and Fe3+ chloride. The chemical reaction of Fe3O4 nanoparticles precipitation is given in Scheme 1 . The magnetic nanoparticles prepared by this method had significant numbers of hydroxyl groups on the surface from contact with the aqueous phase. For grafting β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer, the isocyanate groups were preliminarily bonded onto the surface of the magnetic nanoparticles by the reaction of hydroxyl groups of magnetic NPs with hexamethylene diisocyanate. Then β-cyclodextrin, was polymerized with hexamethylene diisocyanate in dry dimethylformamide and in the presence of modified magnetic nanoparticles (Scheme 2 ). The grafting of β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer on surfaces of magnetic nanoparticles was verified by FT-IR studies. Fig. 1 shows the FT-IR spectra of HMDI, β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane, MNPs and β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer grafted onto Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles in the 500–4000cm−1 wavenumber range. It shows that the characteristic absorption band of FeO bonds in the tetrahedral sites is 580cm−1 [20] which is shifted to 594cm−1 after surface modification with cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer. The IR spectrum of the β-CDPU-MNPs show characteristic adsorption bands at 3360 and 1630cm−1 correspond to NH and CO groups. The NHCO stretching was also observed at 1570cm−1. The presence as well as the degree of crystallinity of magnetic iron oxide (Fe3O4) in β-CDPU-MNPs was obtained from XRD measurements (Fig. 2 ). The pattern of β-CDPU-MNPs displays a most intense at 2θ =34.56. This line corresponds that of pure Fe3O4 [21], confirming the presence of Fe3O4. The observed sharpness and higher intensity of that line relative to that of pure Fe3O4, indicating the higher degree of crystallinity of Fe3O4 particles in β-CDPU-MNPs. In addition, XRD pattern of β-CDPU-MNPs exhibits some peaks at around 2θ from 22 to 26 degree that are attributed to the cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer [22,23]. Fig. 3 shows the TGA analysis of β-CDPU-MNPs. One can observe from the thermogram that the sample exhibits a three-stage degradation pattern over the range of 30–600°C. The first weight loss of 10% below 300°C which might be due to the loss of the adsorbed water as well as dehydration of the surface OH groups. The second weight loss step of about 58% in the region of 305–370°C was due to the cleavage of the urethane linkage, which is quite high compared to conventional polyurethanes which generally start to decompose around 200–220°C. The enhanced thermal stability of β-CDPU-MNPs is attributed to the crosslinked nature. The last stage of degradation in the region of 370–500°C, probably, is due to thermal decomposition of cyclodextrin. Thus, the TGA curves also confirm the successful grafting of β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer onto the magnetic surface. The total weight loss over the full temperature range is estimated to be 83% due to the loss of the adsorbed water and organic units. The amount of magnetic iron oxide (Fe3O4) was evaluated by deducting the total weight loss, whose value was obtained from the TGA curve. From these data, the amount of MNPs is estimated to be 17%. This value could be confirmed by atomic absorption spectroscopy.Atomic absorption spectroscopy (A.A.S.) was also applied to assess the organic content over the support surface of the synthesized nanocomposite. A GBC (Avanta) Atomic Absorption spectrometer fitted with a Fe hollow cathode lamp (Unicam, Franklin, MA) was used to perform atomic absorption measurements. The wavelength of 248.3nm and spectral bandpass of 0.50nm were used throughout. An air–acetylene flame was used for the determination of the Fe ions. The atomic absorption measurements of β-CDPU-MNPs displays about 10.4% Fe at 0.1g of sample. So it is clear that there are nearly 85.6% of cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer on the Fe3O4 particles. The structural and morphological characterization of Fe3O4 and β-CDPU-MNPs nanostructure were performed by measuring SEM using a Philips XL30 scanning electron microscope. The surface morphologies of the uncoated Fe3O4 nanoparticles and β-CDPU-MNPs were shown in Figs. 4 and 5 . As shown in Fig. 5, β-CDPU-MNPs gives thin plates with imbedded Fe3O4. TEM micrographs provide more accurate information on the particle size, morphology and loading of polymers on the support surface. These nanoparticles consist of irregular β-CDPU polymers and have a narrows size distribution (mostly between 17 and 20nm) with an average diameter of 18nm, much smaller than the sizes obtained from the SEM measurements. As shown in Fig. 6 , the fabricated nanocomposite have high loading of polymers on the support surface that could be prohibited real close contact of nanoparticles to reduce their mutual attraction. The magnetic properties of the uncoated magnetic iron oxide (Fe3O4) and β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer coated Fe3O4 nanoparticles were measured by vibrating sample magnetometer, VSM, at room temperature (Fig. 7 ). The VSM technique is used to measure the magnetization value of magnetic particles under applied magnetic field. For particles with superparamagnetic properties, when the applied magnetic field is removed, they should exhibit no coercivity and remanence. In Fig. 6, the hysteresis loops that are characteristic of superparamagnetic behavior can be clearly observed for both MNPs and β-CDPU-MNPs. Superparamagnetism is the responsiveness to an applied magnetic field without retaining any magnetism after removal of the applied magnetic field. From M vs. H curves, the saturation magnetization value (Ms) of uncoated MNPs was found to be 68emug−1. For β-CDPU-MNPs, the magnetization obtained at the same field was 7emug−1, lower than that of uncoated Fe3O4. This is mainly attributed to the existence of nonmagnetic materials (β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer) on the surface of nanoparticles. This interesting magnetic property could ensure that this superparamagnetic composite is easily manipulated by a magnet in the separation process. In addition, the combination of the magnetic properties of iron oxide with guest-host inclusion complexing behavior of β-CD suggests that this nano composite has great potential to be used as phase transfer catalyst in organic synthesis. 3.2 Application of β-CDPU-MNPs as nanomagnetic polymer brush catalyst for nucleophilic substitution reactions in water Even though some anticancer natural products, drug candidates, synthetic intermediates, antiasthmatic, biocidal and insecticides possess thiocyanate, cyanide, azide or acetate functional groups, there are few reported practical synthetic routes in the literature for these class of compounds [24–28]. Owing to the widespread applications of the described compounds, and in continuation of our previous research on using water as reaction medium [25,29–31] and our interest in developing a true water tolerant catalyst using inexpensive and nonpolluting reagents [30–32], herein we report the synthetic applicability of β-CDPU-MNPs as novel nanomagnetic polymer brush catalyst for the rapid, and efficient preparation of benzyl thiocyanates, cyanides, azides and acetates in water by nucleophilic substitution reaction (Scheme 3 ). In order to investigate the possible catalytic properties of β-CDPU-MNPs in the nucleophilic substitution reaction, the reaction of benzyl halides with thiocyanate anion in water was chosen. Initially, the mixture of benzyl chloride and NH4SCN in water was chosen as the model reaction to determine whether the use of polymeric phase transfer catalyst was efficient and to investigate the optimized conditions. After some experiments (Table 1), it was found that the use of 2 equiv. of NH4SCN per benzyl chloride in the presence of β-CDPU-MNPs (0.1g) in water were the best condition and after stirring for 10min at 90°C, the clean formation of a product with lower Rf value was observed. It should be pointed out that in the absence of β-CDPU-MNPs, the reaction was sluggish and even after prolonged reaction time a considerable amount of starting material was remained. Moreover, the reaction mixture was contaminated with alcohol. The success of the conversion of benzyl chloride to benzyl thiocyanate using β-CDPU-MNPs as nanomagnetic solid–liquid phase-transfer catalyst and molecular host system encouraged us to enlarge the scope of the reaction to other benzyl halides and nucleophiles (Table 2 ). In all cases, a very clean reaction was observed. It is noteworthy that no evidence for the formation of by-products such as alcohols or isothiocyanates were observed and the products obtained in pure form without further purification. 13C resonance of the SCN and NCS groups at ∼111 and ∼145ppm, respectively, are very characteristic for thiocyanate and isothiocyanate functionalities [25]. However, when an immobilized biocatalyst is prepared, it should be considered that the main goal of enzyme immobilization should be the reuse of the biocatalyst [33]. It is worthy to note that β-CDPU-MNPs does not suffer from extensive mechanical degradation after operating and could be quantitatively recovered without filtration since the β-CDPU-MNPs was rapidly concentrated as soon as an external magnet was set close to the sidewall of the reaction vessel. The residual catalyst was washed with water and methanol and dried, then immediately reused for the next run. The recovered resin has been reused ten times for the nucleophilic substitution reaction of benzyl chloride with thiocyanate anion. The results illustrated in Graph 1 showed that the catalyst can be used ten times without appreciable loss in its activity (Graph 1). With this promising result in hand and establishing the advantages of β-CDPU-MNPs as nanomagnetic solid–liquid phase-transfer catalyst, we focused our attention in the other nucleophilic substitution reactions, conversion of benzyl halides to the corresponding cyanides, azides and acetates. Table 2 summarizes the data and clearly shown that the desired products were formed in good isolated yields and no side products were observed.A comparison of the efficacy of β-CDPU-MNPs catalyst with some of those reported in the literature is presented in Table 3 . As it is seen in addition to having the general advantages attributed to the nanocatalysts, β-CDPU-MNPs is an equally or more efficient catalyst for nucleophilic substitution reaction of benzyl halides in terms of yield and reaction rate.The catalytic activity of β-CDPU-MNPs in nucleophilic substitution reaction could be attributed to the fact that β-CD unit in nanocomposite consists of seven d-glucopyranose monomers covalently bound by α-1,4-linkages. From a topological point of view, this macrocycle can be described as a truncated cone, in which the narrow rim (∼6.4A) bears the primary hydroxyl group whereas the wide rim (∼15.4A) bears the secondary OH groups [39]. Since no hydroxyl group is present within the toroidal cavity of β-CD, this zone of the molecule has a pronounced hydrophobic character. Thus in water, hydrophobic central cavities of β-CD units in β-CDPU polymer can be act as microvessel and accommodate nonpolar alkyl halides. On the other hand, the interior of the β-CD cavity may be more hydrophobic because nonbonding electron pairs of the glycosidic oxygen are present along with a high electron density and Lewis-base properties. Thus the outer OH of the β-CD cavity formed complexes with cations and these complexes cause the anion to be activated. 4 Conclusion In the present work, β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer grafted onto Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles were successfully prepared and their performance as solid–liquid phase-transfer catalyst for nucleophilic substitution reactions of benzyl halides in water was investigated. With the host effects of β-CD and superparamagnetism of iron oxide, β-CDPU-MNPs are expected to have higher potential applications in substitution reactions of benzyl halides. The results revealed that water insoluble nanomagnetic polymer brush catalyst combine easy availability, good stability and excellent catalytic activity that represent a valid alternative to the water soluble β-CD. In conclusion, we have developed a easy way to operate, safe and cost-effective method for the preparation of benzyl thiocyanates, azides, cyanides and acetates in water by nucleophilic substitution reaction. Extensive research to use this nanomagnetic solid–liquid phase transfer catalyst system in organic transformation is currently underway in our group and will be reported in due course. coredata.dc:description: The polymer coated magnetic nanoparticles has gained significant attention for potential applications in biomedicine, separations, and magnetic storage. In this study, β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer coated Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticle as a novel class of hybrid organic/inorganic molecular catalyst was successfully prepared and evaluated as solid–liquid phase-transfer catalyst and molecular host system for nucleophilic substitution reactions. The nanocomposite has demonstrated the ability to catalytic the nucleophilic substitution reaction of benzyl halides with thiocyanate, azide, cyanide and acetate anions in water. No evidence for the formation of by-products for example isothiocyanate or alcohol was observed and the products obtained in pure form without further purification. The nanomagnetic polymer brush catalyst was easily removed from solution via application of a magnetic field, allowing straightforward recovery and reuse. Results obtained from scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and vibrating sample magnetometery (VSM) show that the synthesized magnetic nanocomposite are superparamagnetic with a mean diameter of 59nm. The grafting of β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer to Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticle is confirmed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR).
coredata.dc:title: Magnetic nanoparticles grafted with β-cyclodextrin–polyurethane polymer as a novel nanomagnetic polymer brush catalyst for nucleophilic substitution reactions of benzyl halides in water
